ai-sn12:2.3.1_0: And what, monastics, is old-age and death?
ai-sn12:2.3.2_0: The old age, decrepitude, broken teeth, grey hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.
ai-sn12:2.3.4_0: The passing away, perishing, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, and laying to rest of the corpse of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.
ai-sn12:2.3.6_0: Such is old age, and such is death.
ai-sn12:2.3.7_0: This is called old age and death.
ai-sn12:2.4.2_0: The rebirth, inception, conception, reincarnation, manifestation of the sets of phenomena, and acquisition of the sense fields of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.
ai-sn12:2.5.2_0: There are these three states of existence.
ai-sn12:2.6.2_0: There are these four kinds of grasping.
ai-sn12:2.6.3_0: grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.
ai-sn12:2.7.2_0: There are these six classes of craving.
ai-sn12:2.7.3_0: craving for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts.
ai-sn12:2.8.2_0: There are these six classes of feeling:
ai-sn12:2.8.3_0: feeling born of contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
ai-sn12:2.9.2_0: There are these six classes of contact.
ai-sn12:2.9.3_0: contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
ai-sn12:2.10.1_0: And what, monks, are the six sense-spheres?
ai-sn12:2.10.2_0: The sense fields of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
ai-sn12:2.10.3_0: This is called, monks, the six sense-spheres.
ai-sn12:2.11.1_0: And what are name and form?
ai-sn12:2.11.2_0: Feeling, perception, intention, contact, and attention—
ai-sn12:2.11.4_0: The four great elementals and bodily-form derived from the great elementals.
ai-sn12:2.11.6_0: This is mind, and this is bodily form.
ai-sn12:2.11.7_0: This is called, monks, mind and bodily form.
ai-sn12:2.12.2_0: There are these six classes of consciousness:
ai-sn12:2.12.3_0: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness.
ai-sn12:2.13.2_0: There are three kinds of choices.
ai-sn12:2.13.3_0: (volitional) processes expressed by way of body, (volitional) processes expressed by way of speech, (volitional) processes expressed by way of mind.
ai-sn12:2.14.2_0: Not knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

ai-sn12:4.1.2_0: “Mendicants, Vipassī the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha had this thought before his awakening, when he was still unawakened but intent on awakening:
ai-sn12:4.1.3_0: ‘Alas, this world has fallen into trouble. It’s born, grows old, dies, passes away, and is reborn,
ai-sn12:4.1.4_0: yet it doesn’t understand how to escape from this suffering, from old age and death.
ai-sn12:4.1.5_0: Oh, when will an escape be found from this suffering, from old age and death?’
ai-sn12:4.2.2_0: ‘When what exists is there old age and death? What is a condition for old age and death?’
ai-sn12:4.2.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.2.4_0: ‘When rebirth exists there’s old age and death. Continued existence is a condition for old age and death.’
ai-sn12:4.3.2_0: ‘When what exists is there rebirth? What is a condition for rebirth?’
ai-sn12:4.3.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.3.4_0: ‘When continued existence exists there’s rebirth. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth.’
ai-sn12:4.4.2_0: ‘When what exists is there continued existence? What is a condition for continued existence?’
ai-sn12:4.4.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.4.4_0: ‘When grasping exists there’s continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for continued existence.’
ai-sn12:4.5.2_0: ‘When what exists is there grasping? What is a condition for grasping?’
ai-sn12:4.5.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.5.4_0: ‘When craving exists there’s grasping. Craving is a condition for grasping.’
ai-sn12:4.6.2_0: ‘When what exists is there craving? What is a condition for craving?’
ai-sn12:4.6.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.6.4_0: ‘When feeling exists there’s craving. Feeling is a condition for craving.’
ai-sn12:4.7.2_0: ‘When what exists is there feeling? What is a condition for feeling?’
ai-sn12:4.7.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.7.4_0: ‘When contact exists there’s feeling. Feeling is a condition for contact.’
ai-sn12:4.8.2_0: ‘When what exists is there contact? What is a condition for contact?’
ai-sn12:4.8.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.8.4_0: ‘When the six sense fields exist there’s contact. Contact is a condition for contact.’
ai-sn12:4.9.2_0: ‘When what exists are there the six sense fields? What is a condition for the six sense fields?’
ai-sn12:4.9.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.9.4_0: ‘When name and form exist there are the six sense fields. Name and form are a condition for the six sense fields.’
ai-sn12:4.10.2_0: ‘When what exists are there name and form? What is a condition for name and form?’
ai-sn12:4.10.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.10.4_0: ‘When consciousness exists there are name and form. Consciousness is a condition for name and form.’
ai-sn12:4.11.2_0: ‘When what exists is there consciousness? What is a condition for consciousness?’
ai-sn12:4.11.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.11.4_0: ‘When choices exist there’s consciousness. Choices are a condition for consciousness.’
ai-sn12:4.12.2_0: ‘When what exists are there choices? What is a condition for choices?’
ai-sn12:4.12.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.12.4_0: ‘When ignorance exists there are choices. Ignorance is a condition for choices.’
ai-sn12:4.13.1_0: And so, ignorance is a condition for choices.
ai-sn12:4.13.2_0: Choices are a condition for consciousness. ...
ai-sn12:4.13.3_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
ai-sn12:4.13.4_0: ‘Origination, origination.’ While Vipassī was intent on awakening, such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in him regarding teachings not learned before from another.
ai-sn12:4.14.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no old age and death? When what ceases do old age and death cease?’
ai-sn12:4.14.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.14.4_0: ‘When rebirth doesn’t exist there’s no old age and death. When rebirth ceases, old age and death cease.’
ai-sn12:4.15.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no rebirth? When what ceases does rebirth cease?’
ai-sn12:4.15.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.15.4_0: ‘When continued existence doesn’t exist there’s no rebirth. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.16.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no continued existence? When what ceases does continued existence cease?’
ai-sn12:4.16.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.16.4_0: ‘When grasping doesn’t exist there’s no continued existence. When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.17.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no grasping? When what ceases does grasping cease?’
ai-sn12:4.17.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.17.4_0: ‘When craving doesn’t exist there’s no grasping. When craving ceases, grasping ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.18.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no craving? When what ceases does craving cease?’
ai-sn12:4.18.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.18.4_0: ‘When feeling doesn’t exist there’s no craving. When feeling ceases, craving ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.19.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no feeling? When what ceases does feeling cease?’
ai-sn12:4.19.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.19.4_0: ‘When contact doesn’t exist there’s no feeling. When contact ceases, feeling ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.20.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no contact? When what ceases does contact cease?’
ai-sn12:4.20.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.20.4_0: ‘When the six sense fields don’t exist there’s no contact. When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.21.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist are there no six sense fields? When what ceases do the six sense fields cease?’
ai-sn12:4.21.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.21.4_0: ‘When name and form don’t exist there are no six sense fields. When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.’
ai-sn12:4.22.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist are there no name and form? When what ceases does name and form cease?’
ai-sn12:4.22.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.22.4_0: ‘When consciousness doesn’t exist there are no name and form. When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.’
ai-sn12:4.23.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no consciousness? When what ceases does consciousness cease?’
ai-sn12:4.23.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.23.4_0: ‘When choices don’t exist there’s no consciousness. When choices cease, consciousness ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.24.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist are there no choices? When what ceases does choices cease?’
ai-sn12:4.24.3_0: Then, through proper attention, Vipassī comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:4.24.4_0: ‘When ignorance doesn’t exist there are no choices. When ignorance ceases, choices cease.’
ai-sn12:4.25.1_0: And so, when ignorance ceases, choices cease.
ai-sn12:4.25.3_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.
ai-sn12:4.25.4_0: ‘Cessation, cessation.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, regarding teachings not learned before from another.”

ai-sn12:11.1.3_0: “Mendicants, there are these four fuels. They maintain sentient beings that have been born and help those that are about to be born.
ai-sn12:11.1.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by four?
ai-sn12:11.1.5_0: solid food, whether coarse or fine; contact is the second, mental intention the third, and consciousness the fourth.
ai-sn12:11.1.6_0: These are the four fuels that maintain sentient beings that have been born and help those that are about to be born.
ai-sn12:11.2.1_0: What is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of these four fuels?
ai-sn12:11.2.2_0: These are the four fuels that give rise to craving.
ai-sn12:11.2.3_0: And what is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of craving?
ai-sn12:11.2.4_0: Feeling is the source of feeling.
ai-sn12:11.2.5_0: And what is the source of feeling?
ai-sn12:11.2.6_0: Contact is the source of feeling.
ai-sn12:11.2.7_0: And what is the source of contact?

ai-sn12:11.2.15_0: And what is the source of choices?
ai-sn12:11.2.16_0: Ignorance is the source of choices.
ai-sn12:11.3.1_0: So, ignorance is a condition for choices.
ai-sn12:11.3.2_0: Choices are a condition for consciousness. ...

ai-sn12:13.1.2_0: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t understand old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation.
ai-sn12:13.1.12_0: They don’t understand choices, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation.

ai-sn12:17.1.4_0: The naked ascetic Kassapa saw the Buddha coming off in the distance.

ai-sn12:17.7.1_1: When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.

ai-sn12:19.1.2_0: “Mendicants, for a fool hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving, this body has been produced.
ai-sn12:19.1.3_0: So there is the duality of this body and external name and form. Contact depends on this duality. When contacted through one or other of the six sense fields, the fool experiences pleasure and pain.
ai-sn12:19.2.1_0: For an astute person who is produced by ignorance, this body has been produced.
ai-sn12:19.2.2_0: So there is the duality of this body and external name and form. Contact depends on this duality. When contacted through one or other of the six sense fields, the astute person experiences pleasure and pain.

ai-sn12:19.5.6_0: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
ai-sn12:19.6.1_0: Rather, the astute person has given up ignorance and given rise to craving, this body has been given up.
ai-sn12:19.6.3_0: The astute person has completed the spiritual journey for the complete ending of suffering.

ai-sn12:19.6.6_0: They’re freed from suffering, I say.

ai-sn12:32.16.1_0: Then soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Sāriputta said to the mendicants,
ai-sn12:32.16.2_0: “Reverends, the first question that the Buddha asked me was something that I’d not previously considered, so I hesitated.
ai-sn12:32.16.3_0: But when the Buddha agreed with my answer, I thought:
ai-sn12:32.16.4_0: ‘If the Buddha were to question me all day on this matter in different words and ways, I could answer all day with different words and ways.
ai-sn12:32.16.5_0: If he were to question me all night,
ai-sn12:32.16.17_0: or seven days and nights, I could answer in different words and ways for seven days and nights.’”

ai-sn12:33.1.2_0: “Mendicants, I will teach forty-four grounds for knowledge.
ai-sn12:33.1.3_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn12:33.2.1_0: “And what are the forty-four grounds for knowledge?
ai-sn12:33.2.2_0: Knowledge of old age and death, knowledge of the origin of old age and death, knowledge of the cessation of old age and death, and knowledge of the practice that leads to the cessation of old age and death.
ai-sn12:33.2.9_0: Knowledge of the six sense fields ...
ai-sn12:33.2.12_0: Knowledge of choices, knowledge of the origin of choices, knowledge of the cessation of choices, and knowledge of the practice that leads to the cessation of choices.
ai-sn12:33.2.13_0: These are called the forty-four grounds for knowledge.
ai-sn12:33.3.1_0: And what, monastics, is old-age and death?
ai-sn12:33.3.2_0: The old age, decrepitude, broken teeth, grey hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.
ai-sn12:33.3.4_0: The passing away, perishing, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, and laying to rest of the corpse of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.
ai-sn12:33.3.6_0: Such is old age, and such is death.
ai-sn12:33.3.7_0: This is called old age and death.
ai-sn12:33.4.1_0: Rebirth is the origin of old age and death.
ai-sn12:33.4.2_0: When rebirth ceases, old age and death cease.
ai-sn12:33.4.3_0: The practice that leads to the cessation of old age and death is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
ai-sn12:33.5.1_0: A noble disciple understands old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation. This is their knowledge of the present phenomenon.
ai-sn12:33.5.2_0: With this present phenomenon that is seen, known, immediate, attained, and fathomed, they infer to the past and future.
ai-sn12:33.6.1_0: Whatever ascetics and brahmins in the past directly knew old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation, all of them directly knew these things in exactly the same way that I do now.
ai-sn12:33.7.1_0: Whatever ascetics and brahmins in the future will directly know old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation, all of them will directly know these things in exactly the same way that I do now.

ai-sn12:34.2.1_0: “And what are the seventy-seven grounds for knowledge?

ai-sn12:34.2.5_0: Also regarding the future: the knowledge that rebirth is a condition for old age and death, and the knowledge that when rebirth doesn’t exist, there is no old age and death.
ai-sn12:34.2.6_0: And also their knowledge that even this knowledge of the stability of natural principles is liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.

ai-sn12:34.3.12_0: Also regarding the future: the knowledge that ignorance is a condition for choices, and the knowledge that when ignorance doesn’t exist, there are no choices.
ai-sn12:34.3.13_0: And also their knowledge that even this knowledge of the stability of natural principles is liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.

ai-sn12:35.1.5_0: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,

ai-sn12:41.2.2_0: ‘I’ve finished with rebirth in hell, the animal realm, and the ghost realm. I’ve finished with all places of loss, bad places, the underworld. I am a stream-enterer! I’m not liable to be reborn in the underworld, and am bound for awakening.’

ai-sn12:41.3.2_0: Anyone who kills living creatures creates dangers and threats both in the present life and in lives to come, and experiences mental pain and sadness. That danger and threat is quelled for anyone who refrains from killing living creatures.
ai-sn12:41.5.1_0: Anyone who commits sexual misconduct creates dangers and threats both in the present life and in lives to come, and experiences mental pain and sadness. That danger and threat is quelled for anyone who refrains from committing sexual misconduct.
ai-sn12:41.6.1_0: Anyone who lies creates dangers and threats both in the present life and in lives to come, and experiences mental pain and sadness. That danger and threat is quelled for anyone who refrains from lying.
ai-sn12:41.7.1_0: Anyone who uses alcoholic drinks that cause negligence creates dangers and threats both in the present life and in lives to come, and experiences mental pain and sadness. That danger and threat is quelled for anyone who refrains from using alcoholic drinks that cause negligence.

ai-sn12:61.1.3_0: “Mendicants, when it comes to this body made up of the four primary elements, an uneducated ordinary person might become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed.
ai-sn12:61.1.5_0: This body made up of the four primary elements is seen to accumulate and disperse, to be taken up and laid to rest.
ai-sn12:61.1.6_0: So an uneducated ordinary person might become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed.
ai-sn12:61.2.1_0: But when it comes to that which is called ‘mind’ or ‘sentience’ or ‘consciousness’, an uneducated ordinary person is unable to become disillusioned, dispassionate, or freed.
ai-sn12:61.2.3_0: Because for a long time they’ve been attached to it, thought of it as their own, and mistaken it:
ai-sn12:61.2.4_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
ai-sn12:61.2.5_0: That’s why, when it comes to this mind, an uneducated ordinary person is unable to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed.
ai-sn12:61.3.1_0: But an uneducated ordinary person would be better off taking this body made up of the four primary elements to be their self, rather than the mind.
ai-sn12:61.3.3_0: This body made up of the four primary elements is seen to last for a year, or for two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, or a hundred years, or even longer.
ai-sn12:61.4.1_0: But that which is called ‘mind’ or ‘sentience’ or ‘consciousness’ arises as one thing and ceases as another all day and all night.
ai-sn12:61.4.2_0: It’s like a monkey moving through the forest. It grabs hold of one branch, lets it go, and grabs another; then it lets that go and grabs yet another.
ai-sn12:61.4.3_0: In the same way, that which is called ‘mind’ or ‘sentience’ or ‘consciousness’ arises as one thing and ceases as another all day and all night.
ai-sn12:61.5.1_0: In this case, a learned noble disciple carefully and properly attends to dependent origination itself:
ai-sn12:61.5.2_0: ‘When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises.
ai-sn12:61.5.3_0: When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases. That is:
ai-sn12:61.5.4_0: that is to say: with ignorance as condition there are (volitional) processes,
ai-sn12:61.5.5_0: Choices are a condition for consciousness. ...
ai-sn12:61.5.6_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
ai-sn12:61.5.7_0: But from the complete fading away and cessation of ignorance, there is the cessation of volitions,
ai-sn12:61.5.9_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’
ai-sn12:61.6.1_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
ai-sn12:61.6.2_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn12:61.6.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”

ai-sn12:65.1.5_0: Oh, when will an escape be found from this suffering, from old age and death?’

ai-sn12:65.1.8_0: Then, through proper attention, I comprehended with wisdom:

ai-sn12:65.2.11_0: Then, through proper attention, I comprehended with wisdom:

ai-sn12:65.2.14_0: ‘When what exists is there consciousness? What is a condition for consciousness?’
ai-sn12:65.2.15_0: Then, through proper attention, I comprehended with wisdom:
ai-sn12:65.2.16_0: ‘When name and form exist there’s consciousness. Name and form are a condition for consciousness.’
ai-sn12:65.3.2_0: This consciousness turns back from name and form, and doesn’t go beyond that.
ai-sn12:65.3.3_0: This is the extent to which one may be reborn, grow old, die, pass away, or reappear. That is: name and form are conditions for consciousness.
ai-sn12:65.3.4_0: with consciousness as condition: mind and bodily form,
ai-sn12:65.3.5_0: because of mind and body: the six sense spheres,

ai-sn12:65.3.7_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

ai-sn12:65.7.1_0: Suppose a person was wandering in a forest grove. They’d see an ancient path that an ancient route traveled by humans in the past.
ai-sn12:65.7.3_0: Following it along, I saw an ancient city, an ancient capital, inhabited by humans in the past. It was lovely, complete with parks, groves, lotus ponds, and embankments.
ai-sn12:65.7.4_0: Then that person would inform a king or their minister:
ai-sn12:65.7.5_0: ‘Please sir, you should know this. While walking through a forest I saw an ancient path, an ancient route traveled by humans in the past.
ai-sn12:65.7.6_0: Following it along I saw an ancient city, an ancient capital, inhabited by humans in the past. It was lovely, complete with parks, groves, lotus ponds, and embankments.
ai-sn12:65.7.8_0: Then that king or their minister would have that city rebuilt.
ai-sn12:65.7.9_0: And after some time that city was successful and prosperous and full of people, attained to growth and expansion.
ai-sn12:65.7.10_0: In the same way, I saw an ancient path, an ancient route traveled by fully awakened Buddhas in the past.
ai-sn12:65.8.1_0: And what is that ancient path, the ancient road traveled by fully awakened Buddhas in the past?
ai-sn12:65.8.4_0: This is that ancient path, the ancient road traveled by fully awakened Buddhas in the past.
ai-sn12:65.8.5_0: Following it along, I directly knew old age and death,
ai-sn12:65.8.8_0: and the practice that leads to their cessation.
ai-sn12:65.8.10_0: Following it along, I directly knew rebirth ...
ai-sn12:65.8.20_0: Following it along, I directly knew choices,
ai-sn12:65.8.23_0: and the practice that leads to their cessation.
ai-sn12:65.8.24_0: Disciple of the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.
ai-sn12:65.8.25_0: And that’s how this spiritual life has become successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.”
ai-sn12:66.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.
ai-sn12:66.1.8_0: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,

ai-sn12:66.1.12_0: But that mendicant didn’t ran away from the Buddha.

ai-sn12:66.2.2_0: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One.
ai-sn12:66.2.3_0: Let the Buddha speak of the inner self-examination. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-sn12:66.2.4_0: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn12:66.3.1_0: “Take a mendicant who performs inner self-examination:
ai-sn12:66.3.2_0: ‘The suffering that arises in the world starting with old age and death takes many and diverse forms.
ai-sn12:66.3.3_0: But what is the source of this suffering? When what exists do old age and death come to be? And when what does not exist do old age and death not come to be?’
ai-sn12:66.3.5_0: ‘The suffering that arises in the world starting with old age and death takes many and diverse forms.
ai-sn12:66.3.6_0: This is the source of this attachment that originates attachment. When attachments come to be, old age and death don’t come to be.’
ai-sn12:66.3.7_0: They understand old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the fitting practice for their cessation.
ai-sn12:66.3.8_0: And they practice in line with that path.
ai-sn12:66.3.9_0: This is called a mendicant who is practicing for the complete ending of suffering, for the cessation of old age and death.
ai-sn12:66.4.2_0: ‘But what is the source of this attachment? When what exists does attachment come to be? And when what does not exist does attachment not come to be?’
ai-sn12:66.4.4_0: ‘The source of this attachment is craving. When craving exists attachments come to be. And when craving doesn’t exist attachments don’t come to be.’
ai-sn12:66.4.5_0: They understand attachments, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation.
ai-sn12:66.4.6_0: And they practice in line with that path.
ai-sn12:66.4.7_0: This is called a mendicant who is practicing for the complete ending of suffering, for the cessation of attachments.
ai-sn12:66.5.2_0: ‘But where does that craving arise and where does it settle?’
ai-sn12:66.5.4_0: ‘That craving arises and settles on whatever in the world seems nice and pleasant.
ai-sn12:66.5.5_0: And in the world what is likeable and pleasing?
ai-sn12:66.5.6_0: The eye in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.
ai-sn12:66.5.11_0: mind in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.’
ai-sn12:66.6.1_0: There were ascetics and brahmins of the past who saw the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as permanent, as pleasurable, as self, as healthy, and as safe.
ai-sn12:66.6.3_0: As their craving grew, their attachments grew.
ai-sn12:66.6.4_0: As their attachments grew, their suffering grew.
ai-sn12:66.6.5_0: And as their suffering grew, they were not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They were not freed from suffering, I say.

ai-sn12:67.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana. ...
ai-sn12:67.1.2_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta,
ai-sn12:67.1.2_1: and after going, he exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn12:67.1.3_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn12:67.1.4_0: “Well, Reverend Sāriputta, are old age and death made by oneself? Or by another? Or by both oneself and another? Or do they arise by chance, not made by oneself or another?”
ai-sn12:67.1.5_0: “No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, old age and death are not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor do they arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.1.6_0: Rather, rebirth is a condition for old age and death.”
ai-sn12:67.2.1_0: “Well, Reverend Sāriputta, is rebirth made by oneself? Or by another? Or by both oneself and another? Or does it arise by chance, not made by oneself or another?”
ai-sn12:67.2.2_0: “No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, rebirth is not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor does it arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.2.3_0: Rather, continued existence is a condition for rebirth.”
ai-sn12:67.3.1_0: “Well, Reverend Sāriputta, is continued existence made by oneself? ...” ...
ai-sn12:67.3.6_0: “Are the six sense fields made by oneself? ...” ...
ai-sn12:67.3.7_0: “Well, Reverend Sāriputta, are name and form made by oneself? Or by another? Or by both oneself and another? Or do they arise by chance, not made by oneself or another?”
ai-sn12:67.3.8_0: “No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, name and form are not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor do they arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.3.9_0: Rather, consciousness is a condition for name and form.”
ai-sn12:67.4.1_0: “Well, Reverend Sāriputta, is consciousness made by oneself? Or by another? Or by both oneself and another? Or do they arise by chance, not made by oneself or another?”
ai-sn12:67.4.2_0: “No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, consciousness is not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor does it arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.4.3_0: Rather, name and form are conditions for consciousness.”
ai-sn12:67.5.1_0: “Just now I understood you to say:
ai-sn12:67.5.2_0: ‘No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, name and form are not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor do they arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.5.3_0: Rather, consciousness is a condition for name and form.’
ai-sn12:67.6.1_0: But I also understood you to say:
ai-sn12:67.6.2_0: ‘No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, consciousness is not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor does it arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.6.3_0: Rather, name and form are conditions for consciousness.’
ai-sn12:67.7.1_0: How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”
ai-sn12:67.7.2_0: “Well then, reverend, I shall give you a simile.
ai-sn12:67.7.3_0: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
ai-sn12:67.7.4_0: Suppose there were two bundles of reeds leaning up against each other.
ai-sn12:67.7.5_0: In the same way, name and form are conditions for consciousness.
ai-sn12:67.7.6_0: with consciousness as condition: mind and bodily form,
ai-sn12:67.7.7_0: because of mind and body: the six sense spheres,
ai-sn12:67.7.8_0: The six sense fields are conditions for contact. ...
ai-sn12:67.7.9_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
ai-sn12:67.7.10_0: If a palm tree is blossoming and worth one measure of grain,
ai-sn12:67.7.11_0: And if the other were to be pulled away, the first would collapse.
ai-sn12:67.7.12_0: In the same way, when name and form cease, consciousness ceases.
ai-sn12:67.7.13_0: from the cessation of consciousness, the cessation of mind and bodily form,
ai-sn12:67.7.14_0: from the cessation of mind and bodily form, the cessation of the six sense spheres,
ai-sn12:67.7.15_0: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases. ...
ai-sn12:67.7.16_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”’”
ai-sn12:67.8.3_0: How well spoken this was by Venerable Sāriputta!
ai-sn12:67.8.4_0: And we can express our agreement with Venerable Sāriputta’s statement on these thirty-six grounds.

ai-sn12:67.9.15_0: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding ignorance, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.
